Answer: There are a long list of things that can be done -- and some cities are already taking the first steps. New York is replacing the city’s obsolete payphone system with the largest, fastest free public Wi-Fi network in the world. Chicago is monitoring things like noise and air quality conditions in real-time through the Array of Things.Some cities are already taking steps to get ready for autonomous vehicles. But even before they are here, there’s a lot cities can do with data to make today’s transportation systems better, safer, faster, and fairer. Answer: Thanks for the A2A. Unfortunately, very little of what is available will be adopted by existing cities within the next decade. There are far too many regulations. Most of those regulations exist to protect entrenched interests; some of them actually serve the stated purpose of protection. Likewise, those interests carefully watch for anything that could displace them from their privileged positions, and usually fight against it with far more skill than those proposing change.This is why I have proposed building a new model city-state from scratch, starting with an MMORPG simulation. In such siThanks for the A2A. Unfortunately, very little of what is available will be adopted by existing cities within the next decade. There are far too many regulations. Most of those regulations exist to protect entrenched interests; some of them actually serve the stated purpose of protection. Likewise, those interests carefully watch for anything that could displace them from their privileged positions, and usually fight against it with far more skill than those proposing change.This is why I have proposed building a new model city-state from scratch, starting with an MMORPG simulation. In such simulations, anything goes. The only question participants care about is whether something works, based on generally accepted metrics.Once such a model meets all of the commonly accepted metrics for quality of life, it can be built in the real world using established processes for creation of a nation state. Singapore is the best example to date, its institutional prejudices notwithstanding.

Answer: None. Nearly every city in the world is fighting to maintain basic services and infrastructure. In 5–10 years we’ll still have the same people (though they’ll be nearing 75) that control most projects now. Those folks don’t want technology now, they’re not going to want it in 5 or 10 years. It’s only after that period of time, with a changing of the guards that we’ll begin to see change happen.

Answer: Jeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, was once asked , “What’s going to change in the next 10 years?”. The interviewer was also hoping to hear the ‘The Next Big Thing’.However, Jeff’s reply was a smile and, “ That is a very interesting question; it’s a very common one. I almost never get the question:With the changing dynamics of markets and human behaviors, it seems difficult to predict the right choice. However, we can predict things that will stay with us and choose what to invest on. Let’s look at Jeff and Amazon. For him the thing that will stJeff Bezos, the CEO of Amazon, was once asked , “What’s going to change in the next 10 years?”. The interviewer was also hoping to hear the ‘The Next Big Thing’.However, Jeff’s reply was a smile and, “ That is a very interesting question; it’s a very common one. I almost never get the question:With the changing dynamics of markets and human behaviors, it seems difficult to predict the right choice. However, we can predict things that will stay with us and choose what to invest on. Let’s look at Jeff and Amazon. For him the thing that will stick with his brand will be timely delivery and low cost. No one in 10 years would like late delivery times and super expensive stuff. So he invested his time and money on improving that and today we see Amazon, a leader in the online market.The secret that Jeff threw at us to find the ‘The Next Big Thing’, is not by looking at something that will drop from the blue but something that will stick with us. That’s where you make money.As to answer the question in relevance to Bitcoin. Just ask yourself, ‘A wise person once answered that with, “

Answer: Quantum Computing.Right now, computers only have two states (electrical impulses, 0s or 1s), so processes scale up at a linear rate: 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 etc.Quantum Computing allows for four states, so processes scale up at an exponential rate: 4, 16, 64, 256 etc.The level of computing power is vastly superior in Quantum Computing, not only allowing more speed than traditional computing, but also allowing us to ask far more data intensive questions than current technology has allowed us to ask.

Blockchain or crypto has made a huge impact in today’s society and I’m more fascinated to learn how it will evolve and co-exist with our existing processes and technology.As we all know, cryptocurrencies are getting a lot attention right now since it already surpassed their current status last year more and more people believed that this can be accepted in our current society. More people aren’t scared to explore new currencies and payment methods removing them from the stigma of these big corporations that just simply monopolizes and just limiting our options.One project which I think have made an impact as I was checking for alternatives when it comes to payment was NavCoin. I’m amazed how independent this platform imagine an open-source, blockchain based Proof of Stake cryptocurrency. Its design is public, nobody owns or controls it, and everyone can take part. The platform run by its users, for users like us - with an incentivised network of nodes verifying payments all around the world.Just a quickie history about it NavCoin, it is a community-run network that was started in 2014. It initially used Proof of Work, but quickly made the shift to Proof of Stake. With no ICO or premine, NavCoin has always been self-funded to ensure a fair distribution and that everyone has a chance to get involved.In short this platform are just one of the platforms that clearly provides solutions that many of us have been trying to resolved. We want cheap, fast and performance-driven tools and not just because we don’t have any other options.Imagine if there are more blockchain platforms that resolves such issues, I doubt people will forget it. Clearly blockchain will not be a trend but it will definitely be passed down as a marvelous discovery in today’s technology.

And all the reading I do.Weirdly enough, would you believe the prescription medicine for early onset type II diabetes called metformin is in all kinds of heavy testing for having the unusual side-effect of lengthening telemerides. I may not have the correct spelling there, which is really sad — I take this stuff! Not to extend my life, but because I do have diabetes type II. But I watched this in not one, two but three documentaries.However, if your blood sugar is normal, do NOT take this. I never will advocate taking ANYI think I can - all that useless knowledge, accumulated over the years. And all the reading I do.Weirdly enough, would you believe the prescription medicine for early onset type II diabetes called metformin is in all kinds of heavy testing for having the unusual side-effect of lengthening telemerides. I may not have the correct spelling there, which is really sad — I take this stuff! Not to extend my life, but because I do have diabetes type II. But I watched this in not one, two but three documentaries.However, if your blood sugar is normal, do NOT take this. I never will advocate taking ANY drug for the wrong reasons, and while we all might wish to live beyond the time we have, this is not the way to do it. I never will advise screwing around with the pancreas (and this will absolutely kill you if you have no issues with it), and believe me, you’ll live longer if you don’t have diabetes. And the type II is much more dangerous; type I means that typically, your pancreas produces zero blood sugar, which is often easier to deal with. Type II is the rogue version, in that it can produce way too much, a lot, a normal amount occasionally, a little, or nothing, with no way of knowing without testing and leaping a strict measurement of it. I have to avoid sugar to be safe, and I am just off enough to require metformin twice a day, right before, during or right after my breakfast and dinner.Even so, I find it interesting that scientists are trying to separate out the telemeride-growth portion of metformin to help extend human life. Personally, I am not one of the people who will take it if it can be safely done (not that there is any proof of this or that it might happen within my lifetime), but because I have long ago made my peace with having and appreciating a finite life. I do not wish to live beyond my expiration date.Thank you. A very interesting question!

Answer: I think first we have to understand why U.S. life expectancy has steadily been declining since the 80’s and why obesity rates have soared.People tend to blame all kinds of things, including lack of exercise and bad diets. I’m not so sure because I am old enough to remember how things used to be. For instance, I remember my great grandmother, a fantastic cook, who spoiled us with delicious pies, cobblers, puddings and cakes. She’d send away for succulent Virginia hams, bake bread, feed us oatmeal and cheerios with plenty of sugar. We’d clamor for her pancakesI think first we have to understand why U.S. life expectancy has steadily been declining since the 80’s and why obesity rates have soared.People tend to blame all kinds of things, including lack of exercise and bad diets. I’m not so sure because I am old enough to remember how things used to be. For instance, I remember my great grandmother, a fantastic cook, who spoiled us with delicious pies, cobblers, puddings and cakes. She’d send away for succulent Virginia hams, bake bread, feed us oatmeal and cheerios with plenty of sugar. We’d clamor for her pancakes and waffles with real butter and real maple syrup. She never exercised. All her life, she was skinny as a rail and so were we.Today, the children are obese as are scads of adults—in most states ranging up to 40%, having doubled between 1995 and 2019. I don’t remember any truly obese children in my schools as I grew up during the 50’s and 60’s. Also, disease affects many more people than it once did and at younger ages. Something has happened.Until recently, I suspected it was something in the food. Only weeks ago I learned the probable truth. It’s what’s NOT in our food any longer—nutrients.In traditional farming, after a crop was harvested, the leaves, stubble and spoiled vegetation were turned over and allowed to decompose for a season in rain and snow, re-enriching the soil. Our foods were full of nutrients, as was our meat and poultry from eating the nutritious crops.When commercial farming arrived, they soon tired of fallow fields. To increase profits, the fields were always under cultivation, continuously depleting the soil. Chemical fertilizers couldn’t keep up.Bottom line, not only do we not ingest the amount of nutrients humans always have needed to fend off illness and disease, but our underfed bodies, seeking nourishment, instinctively urge us to eat more and more and more. On the average diet, we can’t get “full” like we once did.This is a very big problem, not only for our present health, but there are predictions that soil depletion is so rapid that our fields won’t be able to produce food at all at some point.There are actually two different debates going on about this, soil erosion and soil depletion, the newer, but related concern. My points refer to depletion.Is this why we are sicker, obese, and our lifespan is declining?I’m almost convinced the answer is yes.

Answer: Advancements in the medical field are being made constantly and as medicine advances, so too does the average life expectancy. A study published in Health Affairs shows that Medicines are responsible for more than a third of the improvement in life expectancy from 1990 to 2015. Basically, life expectancy increased by 3.3 years in that period alone.A lot of different things are being researched all the time but one that really interests me is the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning to help physicians select more effective medications, medication combinations, and dosages to imprAdvancements in the medical field are being made constantly and as medicine advances, so too does the average life expectancy. A study published in Health Affairs shows that Medicines are responsible for more than a third of the improvement in life expectancy from 1990 to 2015. Basically, life expectancy increased by 3.3 years in that period alone.A lot of different things are being researched all the time but one that really interests me is the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning to help physicians select more effective medications, medication combinations, and dosages to improve control of hypertension.Hypertension is defined as a condition in which the force of the blood against the artery walls is too high.It’s crazy just how dangerous hypertension is. Often referred to as the “silent killer”, high blood pressure usually doesn’t show any major symptoms early on but it significantly increases the chances of many major health complications like heart failure and stroke. It is also extremely common nowadays but is hard to detect until it’s too lateAccording to the Cleveland Clinic Website… “AI also will allow physicians to predict cardiovascular morbidities and enable physicians to focus on interventions before they occur”I think technology like this will really help to prolong human life by a fair bit, especially seeing how it’s difficult to find someone these days who doesn’t have a history with high blood pressure.And please, go get your blood pressure checkedReferences

Answer: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy might.I read an article claiming that an Israeli doctor had reversed aging using hyperbaric oxygen therapy administered at doses of 3.0 atmopsheres of pure oxygen.It is my opinion that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (or at least the ability to compress air, create a vacuum, and isolate and purify the gases that make up the earth’s atmosphere, including oxygen) was actually discovered by the scientists in the time of Hellenistic Greece and was passed down among a secret group of initiates throughout the Roman Empire, and that this technology was rediscovered in the 16th cenHyperbaric oxygen therapy might.I read an article claiming that an Israeli doctor had reversed aging using hyperbaric oxygen therapy administered at doses of 3.0 atmopsheres of pure oxygen.It is my opinion that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (or at least the ability to compress air, create a vacuum, and isolate and purify the gases that make up the earth’s atmosphere, including oxygen) was actually discovered by the scientists in the time of Hellenistic Greece and was passed down among a secret group of initiates throughout the Roman Empire, and that this technology was rediscovered in the 16th century by Robert Boyle and other scientists, and gradually evolved to become hyperbaric oxygen therapy in the 20th century as medical uses for it were found.
